title: Trump says he hopes to mediate between Turkey and Syria's Kurds as EU mulls sanctions
text:
President Donald Trump said the US may step in to mediate between Turkey and the Kurds as Ankara was threatened with the possibility of EU sanctions over its incursion into northern Syria.

Mr Trump’s green light for Turkish leader Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s offensive has turned amber under international pressure, with the US president warning Turkey if it went too far he would destroy the country’s economy.

"We have one of three choices,” he tweeted on Thursday night. “Send in thousands of troops and win militarily, hit Turkey very hard financially and with sanctions, or mediate a deal between Turkey and the Kurds!"

“I hope we can mediate,” he told reporters later when asked about the options.

Facing increasing pressure to rein in Turkish forces, and allied Syrian rebels, the US set down red lines for their offensive on Kurdish-held areas along the Turkish border.

Civilians flee amid Turkish bombardment on Syria's northeastern town of Ras al-Ain in the Hasakeh province along the Turkish border Credit: AFP More

“That would include ethnic cleansing. It would include in particular indiscriminate artillery, air and other fire directed at civilian population,” a senior US official said, spelling out what Turkish actions would trigger US sanctions.

“That is what we’re looking at right now. We have not seen significant examples of that so far.”

Turkey claimed to have killed as many as 277 fighters from the Kurdish People’s Protection Units (YPG) as it tried to take villages around the border towns of Tel Abyad and Ras al-Ayn, while reporting one to its own military.

Some 11 civilians have been reportedly killed by the Kurdish Red Crescent, while a similar number of Turkish civilian casualties is believed to have been sustained.

Mr Trump warned Turkey to act with moderation and safeguard civilians. But the barrages of the invasion so far showed little sign of holding back.

A picture taken from Turkish territory shows smoke rising from targets inside Syria during bombardment by Turkish forces at Ras al-Ayn town Credit: REX More

Residents along the border fled with their belongings loaded into cars, pickup trucks and motorcycle rickshaws, while others escaped on foot.

The UN refugee agency said tens of thousands were on the move, and aid agencies warned that nearly a half-million people near the border were at risk.

France, which has come out strongly against the assault, said the EU would discuss imposing sanctions on Turkey at a summit next week.

US senators, meanwhile, have been drawing up plans for their own possible sanctions.
